document.docAuthor: Ivie, Michael A. & Hart, Charles J.
document.docTitle: Blapstinus punctatus Ivie & Hart 2016, n. sp.
document.masterDocTitle: Redefinition ofDiastolinusMulsant and Rey, with a Review of West Indian Blapstinoid Genera (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae: Opatrini)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redefinition ofDiastolinusMulsant and Rey, with a Review of West Indian Blapstinoid Genera (Coleoptera: Tenebrionidae: Opatrini)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Blaps punctata Fabricius 1792: 109
( type locality: St. Thomas);
Schönherr 1806: 146
.

Clapstinus punctatus
;
Marcuzzi 1957: 129
(in part, Puerto Rico , St. Thomas, St. John records only).

Blapstinus sp.
fuscicornis
possibly
punctatus
;
Wolcott 1923: 96
( Puerto Rico ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. San Salvador, Mona, Puerto Rico , Isla Maguey* (PR, NMNH), Culebra* (AMNH), St. Thomas, Buck Is.* (STT, WIBF), St. John, Tortola * (FMNH, NMNH, WIBF), Guana (TOR), St. Croix.

Remarks. Based on Chevrolat’ s description,
D . fuscicornis
is not any of the Puerto Rican
Diastolinus
, and fits better with
Blapstinus
. We looked for the type in the BMNH, MNHN, and MHNL, and did not find it. It is likely the type will be found in the Gundlach collection in the Instituto de Ecología y Sistemática (IES) in La Habana, since Chevrolat mentioned it as the source. Gundlach (1894) , in his faunal treatment of Puerto Rico , listed this species as follows:

Diastolinus fusciornis Chevr., Bull. Soc. Ent. Fr.
18, p. viii.

The
nomen nudum
Blapstinus scutellaris Chevrolat
under
Diastolinus fuscicornis Chevrolat
fits a specimen that Garrido and Gutiérrez (1996a) mention as Gundlach specimen #l076 in the IES, Havana . They report it having the labels “
Blapstinus scutellaris
,
Diastolinus fuscicornis Chevrolat
,
Blapstinus scutellaris Chevrolat
, recibido por Poey”. Although Garrido and Gutiérrez clearly think this specimen is from Cuba , it seems possible this is the Chevrolat type from Puerto Rico . We were unable to further study this specimen. After carefully comparing the description with all known Puerto Rican species,
D fuscicornis
seems to belong rather clearly to
B . punctatus
. The Marcuzzi records are simply repeating the Chevrolat record. Later, Garrido (2002) used the name
D. fuscicornis
for what we consider to be
Diastolinus clavatus
, a species that cannot be the one Chevrolat described, and that record is removed to
D . clavatus
.

The Puerto Rican records under the name
B. striatulatus
date to
Wolcott (1936)
, who followed Chapin’ s determination of a series of specimens sent to the USNM. These five specimens are in the collection there, under the name “
Blapstinus striatulatus Mels, C.
” The label reads “ Isabela ,;
20 VI 1931
/ Porto Rico ; G. N. Wolcott .” Also in this series are two specimens labeled “St. Croix; Danish W.I./ Dr. L. Smith ; collector.” One of the St. Croix specimens actually bears the Chapin identification label
.
